trans-unit.source: Enable HTTPS for a web app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Enable HTTPS for a web app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Get going faster--use the NEW Azure <link><linkText>guided walkthrough</linkText><title></title></link>!
trans-unit.target: Get going faster--use the NEW Azure <link><linkText>guided walkthrough</linkText><title></title></link>!

trans-unit.source: It makes associating a custom domain name AND securing communication (SSL) with Azure Cloud Services or <link><linkText>App Service</linkText><title></title></link> a snap.
trans-unit.target: It makes associating a custom domain name AND securing communication (SSL) with Azure Cloud Services or <link><linkText>App Service</linkText><title></title></link> a snap.

trans-unit.source: You can secure the communication between the web app and the browser with HTTPS, which uses Secure Socket Layer (SSL) encryption.
trans-unit.target: You can secure the communication between the web app and the browser with HTTPS, which uses Secure Socket Layer (SSL) encryption.

trans-unit.source: This is the most commonly used method of securing data sent across the internet, and assures visitors that their transactions with your App are secure.
trans-unit.target: This is the most commonly used method of securing data sent across the internet, and assures visitors that their transactions with your App are secure.

trans-unit.source: This article discusses how to configure HTTPS for a web app in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: This article discusses how to configure HTTPS for a web app in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: This article does not cover client certificate authentication; for information about that, see <link><linkText>How To Configure TLS Mutual Authentication for Web Apps</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This article does not cover client certificate authentication; for information about that, see <link><linkText>How To Configure TLS Mutual Authentication for Web Apps</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>HTTPS for the \*.azurewebsites.net domain
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>HTTPS for the \*.azurewebsites.net domain

trans-unit.source: If you are not planning on using a custom domain name, but are instead planning on using the \*.azurewebsites.net domain assigned to your web app by Azure (for example, contoso.azurewebsites.net) then HTTPS is already enabled on your site with a certificate from Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: If you are not planning on using a custom domain name, but are instead planning on using the \*.azurewebsites.net domain assigned to your web app by Azure (for example, contoso.azurewebsites.net) then HTTPS is already enabled on your site with a certificate from Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: You can use https://mywebsite.azurewebsites.net to access your App.
trans-unit.target: You can use https://mywebsite.azurewebsites.net to access your App.

trans-unit.source: However, \*.azurewebsites.net is a wildcard domain.
trans-unit.target: However, \*.azurewebsites.net is a wildcard domain.

trans-unit.source: Like <link><linkText>all wildcard domains</linkText><title></title></link>, it is not as secure as using a custom domain with your own certificate.
trans-unit.target: Like <link><linkText>all wildcard domains</linkText><title></title></link>, it is not as secure as using a custom domain with your own certificate.

trans-unit.source: The rest of this document provides details on enabling HTTPS for custom domains, such as contoso.com, www.contoso.com, or \*.contoso.com
trans-unit.target: The rest of this document provides details on enabling HTTPS for custom domains, such as contoso.com, www.contoso.com, or \*.contoso.com

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Enable SSL for your custom domain
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Enable SSL for your custom domain

trans-unit.source: To enable HTTPS for a custom domain, such as contoso.com, you must first register a custom domain name with a domain name registrar.
trans-unit.target: To enable HTTPS for a custom domain, such as contoso.com, you must first register a custom domain name with a domain name registrar.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to configure the domain name of a web app, see <link><linkText>Configuring a custom domain name for an Azure Web Site</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to configure the domain name of a web app, see <link><linkText>Configuring a custom domain name for an Azure Web Site</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Once you have registered a custom domain name and configured your web app to respond to the custom name, you must request an SSL certificate for the domain.
trans-unit.target: Once you have registered a custom domain name and configured your web app to respond to the custom name, you must request an SSL certificate for the domain.

trans-unit.source: In order to enable HTTPS for custom domain names, you must configure your web app for Standard mode.
trans-unit.target: In order to enable HTTPS for custom domain names, you must configure your web app for Standard mode.

trans-unit.source: This may incur additional costs if you are currently using free or shared mode.
trans-unit.target: This may incur additional costs if you are currently using free or shared mode.

trans-unit.source: For more information on shared and Standard pricing, see Pricing Details[pricing].
trans-unit.target: For more information on shared and Standard pricing, see Pricing Details[pricing].

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Get an SSL certificate
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Get an SSL certificate

trans-unit.source: Before requesting an SSL certificate you must first determine which domain names will be secured by the certificate.
trans-unit.target: Before requesting an SSL certificate you must first determine which domain names will be secured by the certificate.

trans-unit.source: This will determine what type of certificate you must obtain.
trans-unit.target: This will determine what type of certificate you must obtain.

trans-unit.source: If you just need to secure a single domain name such as contoso.com or www.contoso.com a basic certificate is sufficient.
trans-unit.target: If you just need to secure a single domain name such as contoso.com or www.contoso.com a basic certificate is sufficient.

trans-unit.source: If you need to secure multiple domain names, such as contoso.com, www.contoso.com, and mail.contoso.com, then you can get a wildcard certificate, or a certificate with Subject Alternate Name (subjectAltName).
trans-unit.target: If you need to secure multiple domain names, such as contoso.com, www.contoso.com, and mail.contoso.com, then you can get a wildcard certificate, or a certificate with Subject Alternate Name (subjectAltName).

trans-unit.source: SSL certificates used with Web Apps must be signed by a <link><linkText>Certificate Authority</linkText><title></title></link> (CA).
trans-unit.target: SSL certificates used with Web Apps must be signed by a <link><linkText>Certificate Authority</linkText><title></title></link> (CA).

trans-unit.source: If you do not already have one, you will need to obtain one from a company that issues SSL certificates.
trans-unit.target: If you do not already have one, you will need to obtain one from a company that issues SSL certificates.

trans-unit.source: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.
trans-unit.target: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.

trans-unit.source: The certificate must meet the following requirements for SSL certificates in Azure:
trans-unit.target: The certificate must meet the following requirements for SSL certificates in Azure:

trans-unit.source: The certificate must contain a private key.
trans-unit.target: The certificate must contain a private key.

trans-unit.source: The certificate must be created for key exchange, exportable to a Personal Information Exchange (.pfx) file.
trans-unit.target: The certificate must be created for key exchange, exportable to a Personal Information Exchange (.pfx) file.

trans-unit.source: The certificate's subject name must match the domain used to access the web app.
trans-unit.target: The certificate's subject name must match the domain used to access the web app.

trans-unit.source: If you need to serve multiple domains with this certificate, you will need to use a wildcard value or specify subjectAltName values as discussed previously.
trans-unit.target: If you need to serve multiple domains with this certificate, you will need to use a wildcard value or specify subjectAltName values as discussed previously.

trans-unit.source: The certificate should use a minimum of 2048-bit encryption.
trans-unit.target: The certificate should use a minimum of 2048-bit encryption.

trans-unit.source: Certificates issued from private CA servers are not supported by Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: Certificates issued from private CA servers are not supported by Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: To get an SSL certificate for use with Azure App Service, you submit a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) to a Certificate Authority and then generate a .pfx file from the certificate you receive back.
trans-unit.target: To get an SSL certificate for use with Azure App Service, you submit a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) to a Certificate Authority and then generate a .pfx file from the certificate you receive back.

trans-unit.source: You can do this using the tool of your choice.
trans-unit.target: You can do this using the tool of your choice.

trans-unit.source: Below are some of the common ways to get a certificate:
trans-unit.target: Below are some of the common ways to get a certificate:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Get a certificate using Certreq.exe</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Get a certificate using Certreq.exe</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Get a certificate using IIS Manager</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Get a certificate using IIS Manager</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Get a certificate using OpenSSL</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Get a certificate using OpenSSL</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Get a SubjectAltName certificate using OpenSSL</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Get a SubjectAltName certificate using OpenSSL</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Generate self-signed certificates (for testing only)</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Generate self-signed certificates (for testing only)</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: When following the steps, you will be prompted to enter a Common Name, such as www.contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: When following the steps, you will be prompted to enter a Common Name, such as www.contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: For wildcard certificates, this value should be \.domainname (for example, \.contoso.com).
trans-unit.target: For wildcard certificates, this value should be \.domainname (for example, \.contoso.com).

trans-unit.source: If you need to support both a wildcard name like \*.contoso.com and a root domain name like contoso.com, you can use a wildcard subjectAltName certificate.
trans-unit.target: If you need to support both a wildcard name like \*.contoso.com and a root domain name like contoso.com, you can use a wildcard subjectAltName certificate.

trans-unit.source: Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) certificates are supported with Azure App Service; however, they are relatively new and you should work with your CA on the exact steps to create the CSR.
trans-unit.target: Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) certificates are supported with Azure App Service; however, they are relatively new and you should work with your CA on the exact steps to create the CSR.

trans-unit.source: You may also need to obtain **<link><linkText>intermediate certificates</linkText><title></title></link>** (also known as chain certificates), if these are used by your CA.
trans-unit.target: You may also need to obtain **<link><linkText>intermediate certificates</linkText><title></title></link>** (also known as chain certificates), if these are used by your CA.

trans-unit.source: The use of intermediate certificates is considered more secure than 'unchained certificates', so it is common for a CA to use them.
trans-unit.target: The use of intermediate certificates is considered more secure than 'unchained certificates', so it is common for a CA to use them.

trans-unit.source: Intermediate certificates are often provided as a separate download from the CAs website.
trans-unit.target: Intermediate certificates are often provided as a separate download from the CAs website.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this article provide steps to ensure that any intermediate certificates are merged with the certificate uploaded to your web apps.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this article provide steps to ensure that any intermediate certificates are merged with the certificate uploaded to your web apps.

trans-unit.source: Get a certificate using Certreq.exe (Windows only)
trans-unit.target: Get a certificate using Certreq.exe (Windows only)

trans-unit.source: Certreq.exe is Windows utility for creating certificate requests.
trans-unit.target: Certreq.exe is Windows utility for creating certificate requests.

trans-unit.source: It has been part of the base Windows installation since Windows XP/Windows Server 2000, so should be available on recent Windows systems.
trans-unit.target: It has been part of the base Windows installation since Windows XP/Windows Server 2000, so should be available on recent Windows systems.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to obtain an SSL certificate using certreq.exe.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to obtain an SSL certificate using certreq.exe.

trans-unit.source: Open Notepad and create a new document that contains the following.
trans-unit.target: Open Notepad and create a new document that contains the following.

trans-unit.source: Replace mysite.com on the Subject line with the custom domain name of your web app.
trans-unit.target: Replace mysite.com on the Subject line with the custom domain name of your web app.

trans-unit.source: For example, Subject = "CN=www.contoso.com".
trans-unit.target: For example, Subject = "CN=www.contoso.com".

trans-unit.source: For more information on the options specified above, as well as other available options, see the <link><linkText>Certreq reference documentationn</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the options specified above, as well as other available options, see the <link><linkText>Certreq reference documentationn</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Save the text file as myrequest.txt.
trans-unit.target: Save the text file as myrequest.txt.

trans-unit.source: From the Start Screen or Start Menu, run cmd.exe.
trans-unit.target: From the Start Screen or Start Menu, run cmd.exe.

trans-unit.source: From the command prompt, use the following command to create the certificate request file:
trans-unit.target: From the command prompt, use the following command to create the certificate request file:

trans-unit.source: Specify the path to the myrequest.txt file created in step 1, and the path to use when creating the myrequest.csr file.
trans-unit.target: Specify the path to the myrequest.txt file created in step 1, and the path to use when creating the myrequest.csr file.

trans-unit.source: Submit the myrequest.csr to a Certificate Authority to obtain an SSL certificate.
trans-unit.target: Submit the myrequest.csr to a Certificate Authority to obtain an SSL certificate.

trans-unit.source: This may involve uploading the file, or opening the file in Notepad and pasting the contents directly into a web form.
trans-unit.target: This may involve uploading the file, or opening the file in Notepad and pasting the contents directly into a web form.

trans-unit.source: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.
trans-unit.target: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.

trans-unit.source: Once the Certificate Authority has provided you with a certificate (.CER) file, save this file to the computer used to generate the request, and then use the following command to accept the request and complete the certificate generation process.
trans-unit.target: Once the Certificate Authority has provided you with a certificate (.CER) file, save this file to the computer used to generate the request, and then use the following command to accept the request and complete the certificate generation process.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the mycert.cer certificate received from the Certificate Authority will be used to complete the signature of the certificate.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the mycert.cer certificate received from the Certificate Authority will be used to complete the signature of the certificate.

trans-unit.source: No file will be created; instead, the certificate will be stored in the Windows certificate store.
trans-unit.target: No file will be created; instead, the certificate will be stored in the Windows certificate store.

trans-unit.source: If your CA uses intermediate certificates, you must install these certificates before exporting the certificate in the next steps.
trans-unit.target: If your CA uses intermediate certificates, you must install these certificates before exporting the certificate in the next steps.

trans-unit.source: Usually these certificates are provided as a separate download from your CA, and are provided in several formats for different web server types.
trans-unit.target: Usually these certificates are provided as a separate download from your CA, and are provided in several formats for different web server types.

trans-unit.source: Select the version that is provided for Microsoft IIS.
trans-unit.target: Select the version that is provided for Microsoft IIS.

trans-unit.source: Once you have downloaded the certificate, right click on it in explorer and select Install certificate.
trans-unit.target: Once you have downloaded the certificate, right click on it in explorer and select Install certificate.

trans-unit.source: Use the default values in the Certificate Import Wizard, and continue selecting Next until the import has completed.
trans-unit.target: Use the default values in the Certificate Import Wizard, and continue selecting Next until the import has completed.

trans-unit.source: To export the certificate from the certificate store, run certmgr.msc from the Start Screen or Start Menu.
trans-unit.target: To export the certificate from the certificate store, run certmgr.msc from the Start Screen or Start Menu.

trans-unit.source: When Certificate Manager appears, expand the Personal folder, and then select Certificates.
trans-unit.target: When Certificate Manager appears, expand the Personal folder, and then select Certificates.

trans-unit.source: In the Issued To field, look for an entry with the custom domain name you requested a certificate for.
trans-unit.target: In the Issued To field, look for an entry with the custom domain name you requested a certificate for.

trans-unit.source: In the Issued By field, it should list the Certificate Authority you used for this certificate.
trans-unit.target: In the Issued By field, it should list the Certificate Authority you used for this certificate.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>insert image of cert manager here</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>insert image of cert manager here</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Right click the certificate and select All Tasks, and then select Export.
trans-unit.target: Right click the certificate and select All Tasks, and then select Export.

trans-unit.source: In the Certificate Export Wizard, click Next and then select Yes, export the private key.
trans-unit.target: In the Certificate Export Wizard, click Next and then select Yes, export the private key.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Export the private key</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Export the private key</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Personal Information Exchange - PKCS #12, Include all certificates in the certificate chain, and Export all extended properties.
trans-unit.target: Select Personal Information Exchange - PKCS #12, Include all certificates in the certificate chain, and Export all extended properties.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>include all certs and extended properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>include all certs and extended properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Password, and then enter and confirm the password.
trans-unit.target: Select Password, and then enter and confirm the password.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>specify a password</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>specify a password</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Provide a path and filename that will contain the exported certificate.
trans-unit.target: Provide a path and filename that will contain the exported certificate.

trans-unit.source: The filename should have an extension of .pfx.
trans-unit.target: The filename should have an extension of .pfx.

trans-unit.source: Click Next to complete the process.
trans-unit.target: Click Next to complete the process.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>provide a file path</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>provide a file path</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can now upload the exported PFX file to your Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: You can now upload the exported PFX file to your Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: Get a certificate using OpenSSL
trans-unit.target: Get a certificate using OpenSSL

trans-unit.source: Generate a private key and Certificate Signing Request by using the following from a command-line, bash or terminal session:
trans-unit.target: Generate a private key and Certificate Signing Request by using the following from a command-line, bash or terminal session:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter the appropriate information.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter the appropriate information.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Once this process completes, you should have two files; myserver.key and server.csr.
trans-unit.target: Once this process completes, you should have two files; myserver.key and server.csr.

trans-unit.source: The server.csr contains the Certificate Signing Request.
trans-unit.target: The server.csr contains the Certificate Signing Request.

trans-unit.source: Submit your CSR to a Certificate Authority to obtain an SSL certificate.
trans-unit.target: Submit your CSR to a Certificate Authority to obtain an SSL certificate.

trans-unit.source: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.
trans-unit.target: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.

trans-unit.source: Once you have obtained a certificate from a CA, save it to a file named myserver.crt.
trans-unit.target: Once you have obtained a certificate from a CA, save it to a file named myserver.crt.

trans-unit.source: If your CA provided the certificate in a text format, simply paste the certificate text into the myserver.crt file.
trans-unit.target: If your CA provided the certificate in a text format, simply paste the certificate text into the myserver.crt file.

trans-unit.source: The file contents should be similar to the following when viewed in a text editor:
trans-unit.target: The file contents should be similar to the following when viewed in a text editor:

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, Bash or terminal session, use the following command to convert the myserver.key and myserver.crt into myserver.pfx, which is the format required by Azure App Service:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, Bash or terminal session, use the following command to convert the myserver.key and myserver.crt into myserver.pfx, which is the format required by Azure App Service:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter a password to secure the .pfx file.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter a password to secure the .pfx file.

trans-unit.source: If your CA uses intermediate certificates, you must install these certificates before exporting the certificate in the next step.
trans-unit.target: If your CA uses intermediate certificates, you must install these certificates before exporting the certificate in the next step.

trans-unit.source: Usually these certificates are provided as a separate download from your CA, and are provided in several formats for different web server types.
trans-unit.target: Usually these certificates are provided as a separate download from your CA, and are provided in several formats for different web server types.

trans-unit.source: Select the version that is provided as a PEM file (.pem file extension.)
trans-unit.target: Select the version that is provided as a PEM file (.pem file extension.)

trans-unit.source: The follow command demonstrates how to create a .pfx file that includes intermediate certificates, which are contained in the intermediate-cets.pem file:
trans-unit.target: The follow command demonstrates how to create a .pfx file that includes intermediate certificates, which are contained in the intermediate-cets.pem file:

trans-unit.source: After running this command, you should have a myserver.pfx file suitable for use with Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: After running this command, you should have a myserver.pfx file suitable for use with Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Get a certificate using the IIS Manager
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Get a certificate using the IIS Manager

trans-unit.source: If you are familiar with IIS Manager, you can use it to generate a certificate that can be used with Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you are familiar with IIS Manager, you can use it to generate a certificate that can be used with Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: Generate a CSR with IIS Manager to send to the Certificate Authority.
trans-unit.target: Generate a CSR with IIS Manager to send to the Certificate Authority.

trans-unit.source: For more information on generating a CSR, see <link><linkText>Request an Internet Server Certificate (IIS 7)[iiscsr]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on generating a CSR, see <link><linkText>Request an Internet Server Certificate (IIS 7)[iiscsr]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Submit your CSR to a Certificate Authority to obtain an SSL certificate.
trans-unit.target: Submit your CSR to a Certificate Authority to obtain an SSL certificate.

trans-unit.source: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.
trans-unit.target: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.

trans-unit.source: Complete the CSR with the certificate provided by the Certificate Authority vendor.
trans-unit.target: Complete the CSR with the certificate provided by the Certificate Authority vendor.

trans-unit.source: For more information on completing the CSR, see <link><linkText>Install an Internet Server Certificate (IIS 7)[installcertiis]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on completing the CSR, see <link><linkText>Install an Internet Server Certificate (IIS 7)[installcertiis]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If your CA uses intermediate certificates, you must install these certificates before exporting the certificate in the next step.
trans-unit.target: If your CA uses intermediate certificates, you must install these certificates before exporting the certificate in the next step.

trans-unit.source: Usually these certificates are provided as a separate download from your CA, and are provided in several formats for different web server types.
trans-unit.target: Usually these certificates are provided as a separate download from your CA, and are provided in several formats for different web server types.

trans-unit.source: Select the version that is provided for Microsoft IIS.
trans-unit.target: Select the version that is provided for Microsoft IIS.

trans-unit.source: Once you have downloaded the certificate, right click on it in explorer and select Install certificate.
trans-unit.target: Once you have downloaded the certificate, right click on it in explorer and select Install certificate.

trans-unit.source: Use the default values in the Certificate Import Wizard, and continue selecting Next until the import has completed.
trans-unit.target: Use the default values in the Certificate Import Wizard, and continue selecting Next until the import has completed.

trans-unit.source: Export the certificate from IIS Manager For more information on exporting the certificate, see <link><linkText>Export a Server Certificate (IIS 7)[exportcertiis]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Export the certificate from IIS Manager For more information on exporting the certificate, see <link><linkText>Export a Server Certificate (IIS 7)[exportcertiis]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The exported file will be used in later steps to upload to Azure for use with your web app.
trans-unit.target: The exported file will be used in later steps to upload to Azure for use with your web app.

trans-unit.source: During the export process, be sure to select the option <html></html>Yes, export the private key<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: During the export process, be sure to select the option <html></html>Yes, export the private key<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: This will include the private key in the exported certificate.
trans-unit.target: This will include the private key in the exported certificate.

trans-unit.source: During the export process, be sure to select the option include all certs in the certification path and Export all extended properties.
trans-unit.target: During the export process, be sure to select the option include all certs in the certification path and Export all extended properties.

trans-unit.source: This will include any intermediate certificates in the exported certificate.
trans-unit.target: This will include any intermediate certificates in the exported certificate.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Get a SubjectAltName certificate using OpenSSL
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Get a SubjectAltName certificate using OpenSSL

trans-unit.source: OpenSSL can be used to create a certificate request that uses the SubjectAltName extension to support multiple domain names with a single certificate, however it requires a configuration file.
trans-unit.target: OpenSSL can be used to create a certificate request that uses the SubjectAltName extension to support multiple domain names with a single certificate, however it requires a configuration file.

trans-unit.source: The following steps walk through creating a configuration file, and then using it to request a certificate.
trans-unit.target: The following steps walk through creating a configuration file, and then using it to request a certificate.

trans-unit.source: Create a new file named sancert.cnf and use the following as the contents of the file:
trans-unit.target: Create a new file named sancert.cnf and use the following as the contents of the file:

trans-unit.source: Note the line that begins with 'subjectAltName'.
trans-unit.target: Note the line that begins with 'subjectAltName'.

trans-unit.source: Replace the domain names currently listed with domain names you wish to support in addition to the common name.
trans-unit.target: Replace the domain names currently listed with domain names you wish to support in addition to the common name.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: You do not need to change the commonName_default field, as you will be prompted to enter your common name in one of the following steps.
trans-unit.target: You do not need to change the commonName_default field, as you will be prompted to enter your common name in one of the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Save the sancert.cnf file.
trans-unit.target: Save the sancert.cnf file.

trans-unit.source: Generate a private key and Certificate Signing Request by using the sancert.cnf configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Generate a private key and Certificate Signing Request by using the sancert.cnf configuration file.

trans-unit.source: From a bash or terminal session, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: From a bash or terminal session, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter the appropriate information.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter the appropriate information.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Once this process completes, you should have two files; myserver.key and server.csr.
trans-unit.target: Once this process completes, you should have two files; myserver.key and server.csr.

trans-unit.source: The server.csr contains the Certificate Signing Request.
trans-unit.target: The server.csr contains the Certificate Signing Request.

trans-unit.source: Submit your CSR to a Certificate Authority to obtain an SSL certificate.
trans-unit.target: Submit your CSR to a Certificate Authority to obtain an SSL certificate.

trans-unit.source: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.
trans-unit.target: For a list of Certificate Authorities, see <link><linkText>Windows and Windows Phone 8 SSL Root Certificate Program (Members CAs)[cas]</linkText><title></title></link> on the Microsoft TechNet Wiki.

trans-unit.source: Once you have obtained a certificate from a CA, save it to a file named myserver.crt.
trans-unit.target: Once you have obtained a certificate from a CA, save it to a file named myserver.crt.

trans-unit.source: If your CA provided the certificate in a text format, simply paste the certificate text into the myserver.crt file.
trans-unit.target: If your CA provided the certificate in a text format, simply paste the certificate text into the myserver.crt file.

trans-unit.source: The file contents should be similar to the following when viewed in a text editor:
trans-unit.target: The file contents should be similar to the following when viewed in a text editor:

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, Bash or terminal session, use the following command to convert the myserver.key and myserver.crt into myserver.pfx, which is the format required by Azure App Service:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, Bash or terminal session, use the following command to convert the myserver.key and myserver.crt into myserver.pfx, which is the format required by Azure App Service:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter a password to secure the .pfx file.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter a password to secure the .pfx file.

trans-unit.source: If your CA uses intermediate certificates, you must install these certificates before exporting the certificate in the next step.
trans-unit.target: If your CA uses intermediate certificates, you must install these certificates before exporting the certificate in the next step.

trans-unit.source: Usually these certificates are provided as a separate download from your CA, and are provided in several formats for different web server types.
trans-unit.target: Usually these certificates are provided as a separate download from your CA, and are provided in several formats for different web server types.

trans-unit.source: Select the version that is provided as a PEM file (.pem file extension.)
trans-unit.target: Select the version that is provided as a PEM file (.pem file extension.)

trans-unit.source: The follow command demonstrates how to create a .pfx file that includes intermediate certificates, which are contained in the intermediate-cets.pem file:
trans-unit.target: The follow command demonstrates how to create a .pfx file that includes intermediate certificates, which are contained in the intermediate-cets.pem file:

trans-unit.source: After running this command, you should have a myserver.pfx file suitable for use with Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: After running this command, you should have a myserver.pfx file suitable for use with Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Generate a self-signed certificate (for testing only)
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Generate a self-signed certificate (for testing only)

trans-unit.source: In some cases you may wish to obtain a certificate for testing, and delay purchasing one from a trusted CA until you go into production.
trans-unit.target: In some cases you may wish to obtain a certificate for testing, and delay purchasing one from a trusted CA until you go into production.

trans-unit.source: Self-signed certificates can fill this gap.
trans-unit.target: Self-signed certificates can fill this gap.

trans-unit.source: A self-signed certificate is a certificate you create and sign as if you were a Certificate Authority.
trans-unit.target: A self-signed certificate is a certificate you create and sign as if you were a Certificate Authority.

trans-unit.source: While this certificate can be used to secure a web app, most browsers will return errors when visiting the site as the certificate was not signed by a trusted CA.
trans-unit.target: While this certificate can be used to secure a web app, most browsers will return errors when visiting the site as the certificate was not signed by a trusted CA.

trans-unit.source: Some browsers may even refuse to allow you to view the site.
trans-unit.target: Some browsers may even refuse to allow you to view the site.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Generate a self-signed certificate using makecert</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Generate a self-signed certificate using makecert</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Generate a self-signed certificate using OpenSSL</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Generate a self-signed certificate using OpenSSL</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Generate a self-signed certificate using makecert
trans-unit.target: Generate a self-signed certificate using makecert

trans-unit.source: You can create a test certificate from a Windows system that has Visual Studio installed by performing the following steps:
trans-unit.target: You can create a test certificate from a Windows system that has Visual Studio installed by performing the following steps:

trans-unit.source: From the Start Menu or Start Screen, search for Developer Command Prompt.
trans-unit.target: From the Start Menu or Start Screen, search for Developer Command Prompt.

trans-unit.source: Finally, right-click Developer Command Prompt and select Run As Administrator.
trans-unit.target: Finally, right-click Developer Command Prompt and select Run As Administrator.

trans-unit.source: If you receive a User Account Control dialog, select Yes to continue.
trans-unit.target: If you receive a User Account Control dialog, select Yes to continue.

trans-unit.source: From the Developer Command Prompt, use the following command to create a new self-signed certificate.
trans-unit.target: From the Developer Command Prompt, use the following command to create a new self-signed certificate.

trans-unit.source: You must substitute serverdnsname with the DNS of your web app.
trans-unit.target: You must substitute serverdnsname with the DNS of your web app.

trans-unit.source: This command will create a certificate that is good between the dates of 01/01/2013 and 01/01/2014, and will store the location in the CurrentUser certificate store.
trans-unit.target: This command will create a certificate that is good between the dates of 01/01/2013 and 01/01/2014, and will store the location in the CurrentUser certificate store.

trans-unit.source: From the Start Menu or Start Screen, search for Windows PowerShell and start this application.
trans-unit.target: From the Start Menu or Start Screen, search for Windows PowerShell and start this application.

trans-unit.source: From the Windows PowerShell prompt, use the following commands to export the certificate created previously:
trans-unit.target: From the Windows PowerShell prompt, use the following commands to export the certificate created previously:

trans-unit.source: This stores the specified password as a secure string in $mypwd, then finds the certificate by using the DNS name specified by the dnsname parameter, and exports to the file specified by the filepath parameter.
trans-unit.target: This stores the specified password as a secure string in $mypwd, then finds the certificate by using the DNS name specified by the dnsname parameter, and exports to the file specified by the filepath parameter.

trans-unit.source: The secure string containing the password is used to secure the exported file.
trans-unit.target: The secure string containing the password is used to secure the exported file.

trans-unit.source: Generate a self-signed certificate using OpenSSL
trans-unit.target: Generate a self-signed certificate using OpenSSL

trans-unit.source: Create a new document named serverauth.cnf, using the following as the contents of this file:
trans-unit.target: Create a new document named serverauth.cnf, using the following as the contents of this file:

trans-unit.source: This specifies the configuration settings required to produce an SSL certificate that can be used by Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: This specifies the configuration settings required to produce an SSL certificate that can be used by Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: Generate a new self-signed certificate by using the following from a command-line, bash or terminal session:
trans-unit.target: Generate a new self-signed certificate by using the following from a command-line, bash or terminal session:

trans-unit.source: This creates a new certificate using the configuration settings specified in the serverauth.cnf file.
trans-unit.target: This creates a new certificate using the configuration settings specified in the serverauth.cnf file.

trans-unit.source: To export the certificate to a .PFX file that can be uploaded to a web app, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: To export the certificate to a .PFX file that can be uploaded to a web app, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter a password to secure the .pfx file.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter a password to secure the .pfx file.

trans-unit.source: The myserver.pfx produced by this command can be used to secure your web app for testing purposes.
trans-unit.target: The myserver.pfx produced by this command can be used to secure your web app for testing purposes.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html><html></html>Configure Standard mode<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html><html></html>Configure Standard mode<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Enabling HTTPS for a custom domain is only available for the Standard mode of web app.
trans-unit.target: Enabling HTTPS for a custom domain is only available for the Standard mode of web app.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to switch to Standard mode.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to switch to Standard mode.

trans-unit.source: Before switching a web app from the Free mode to Standard mode, you should remove spending caps in place for your web app subscription, otherwise you risk your site becoming unavailable if you reach your caps before the billing period ends.
trans-unit.target: Before switching a web app from the Free mode to Standard mode, you should remove spending caps in place for your web app subscription, otherwise you risk your site becoming unavailable if you reach your caps before the billing period ends.

trans-unit.source: For more information on shared and Standard mode pricing, see Pricing Details[pricing].
trans-unit.target: For more information on shared and Standard mode pricing, see Pricing Details[pricing].

trans-unit.source: In your browser, open the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: In your browser, open the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click the Browse option on the left side of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click the Browse option on the left side of the page.

trans-unit.source: Click the Web Apps blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Web Apps blade.

trans-unit.source: Click the name of your web app.
trans-unit.target: Click the name of your web app.

trans-unit.source: In the Essentials page, click Settings.
trans-unit.target: In the Essentials page, click Settings.

trans-unit.source: Click Scale
trans-unit.target: Click Scale

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The scale tab</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The scale tab</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Scale section, set the App Service plan mode by clicking Select.
trans-unit.target: In the Scale section, set the App Service plan mode by clicking Select.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The Pricing tier</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The Pricing tier</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you receive a "Configuring scale for web app '<app name>' failed" error you can use the details button to get more information.
trans-unit.target: If you receive a "Configuring scale for web app '<app name>' failed" error you can use the details button to get more information.

trans-unit.source: You may receive a "Not enough available standard instance servers to satisfy this request."
trans-unit.target: You may receive a "Not enough available standard instance servers to satisfy this request."

trans-unit.source: error.
trans-unit.target: error.

trans-unit.source: If you receive this error, please contact <link><linkText>Azure support</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you receive this error, please contact <link><linkText>Azure support</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Configure SSL
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Configure SSL

trans-unit.source: Before performing the steps in this section, you must have associated a custom domain name with your web app.
trans-unit.target: Before performing the steps in this section, you must have associated a custom domain name with your web app.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configuring a custom domain name for a web app[customdomain]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configuring a custom domain name for a web app[customdomain]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In your browser, open the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: In your browser, open the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click the Browse option on the left side of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click the Browse option on the left side of the page.

trans-unit.source: Click the Web Apps blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Web Apps blade.

trans-unit.source: Click the name of your web app.
trans-unit.target: Click the name of your web app.

trans-unit.source: In the Essentials page, click Settings.
trans-unit.target: In the Essentials page, click Settings.

trans-unit.source: Click Custom domains and SSL.
trans-unit.target: Click Custom domains and SSL.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The config tab</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The config tab</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the certificates section, click Upload
trans-unit.target: In the certificates section, click Upload

trans-unit.source: Using the Upload a certificate dialog, select the .pfx certificate file created earlier using the IIS Manager or OpenSSL.
trans-unit.target: Using the Upload a certificate dialog, select the .pfx certificate file created earlier using the IIS Manager or OpenSSL.

trans-unit.source: Specify the password, if any, that was used to secure the .pfx file.
trans-unit.target: Specify the password, if any, that was used to secure the .pfx file.

trans-unit.source: Finally, click the Save to upload the certificate.
trans-unit.target: Finally, click the Save to upload the certificate.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>ssl upload</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>ssl upload</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the ssl bindings section of the SSL Settings tab, use the dropdowns to select the domain name to secure with SSL, and the certificate to use.
trans-unit.target: In the ssl bindings section of the SSL Settings tab, use the dropdowns to select the domain name to secure with SSL, and the certificate to use.

trans-unit.source: You may also select whether to use <link><linkText>Server Name Indication[sni]</linkText><title></title></link> (SNI) or IP based SSL.
trans-unit.target: You may also select whether to use <link><linkText>Server Name Indication[sni]</linkText><title></title></link> (SNI) or IP based SSL.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>ssl bindings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>ssl bindings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: IP based SSL associates a certificate with a domain name by mapping the dedicated public IP address of the server to the domain name.
trans-unit.target: IP based SSL associates a certificate with a domain name by mapping the dedicated public IP address of the server to the domain name.

trans-unit.source: This requires each domain name (contoso.com, fabricam.com, etc.)
trans-unit.target: This requires each domain name (contoso.com, fabricam.com, etc.)

trans-unit.source: associated with your service to have a dedicated IP address.
trans-unit.target: associated with your service to have a dedicated IP address.

trans-unit.source: This is the traditional method of associating SSL certificates with a web server.
trans-unit.target: This is the traditional method of associating SSL certificates with a web server.

trans-unit.source: SNI based SSL is an extension to SSL and <link><linkText>Transport Layer Security[tls]</linkText><title></title></link> (TLS) that allows multiple domains to share the same IP address, with separate security certificates for each domain.
trans-unit.target: SNI based SSL is an extension to SSL and <link><linkText>Transport Layer Security[tls]</linkText><title></title></link> (TLS) that allows multiple domains to share the same IP address, with separate security certificates for each domain.

trans-unit.source: Most modern browsers (including Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox and Opera) support SNI, however older browsers may not support SNI.
trans-unit.target: Most modern browsers (including Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox and Opera) support SNI, however older browsers may not support SNI.

trans-unit.source: For more information on SNI, see the <link><linkText>Server Name Indication[sni]</linkText><title></title></link> article on Wikipedia.
trans-unit.target: For more information on SNI, see the <link><linkText>Server Name Indication[sni]</linkText><title></title></link> article on Wikipedia.

trans-unit.source: Click Save to save the changes and enable SSL.
trans-unit.target: Click Save to save the changes and enable SSL.

trans-unit.source: If you selected IP based SSL and your custom domain is configured using an A record, you must perform the following additional steps:
trans-unit.target: If you selected IP based SSL and your custom domain is configured using an A record, you must perform the following additional steps:

trans-unit.source: 1. After you have configured an IP based SSL binding, a dedicated IP address is assigned to your web app.
trans-unit.target: 1. After you have configured an IP based SSL binding, a dedicated IP address is assigned to your web app.

trans-unit.source: You can find this IP address on the Dashboard page of your web app, in the quick glance section.
trans-unit.target: You can find this IP address on the Dashboard page of your web app, in the quick glance section.

trans-unit.source: It will be listed as Virtual IP Address:
trans-unit.target: It will be listed as Virtual IP Address:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Virtual IP address</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Virtual IP address</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note that this IP address will be different than the virtual IP address used previously to configure the A record for your domain.
trans-unit.target: Note that this IP address will be different than the virtual IP address used previously to configure the A record for your domain.

trans-unit.source: If you are configured to use SNI based SSL, or are not configured to use SSL, no address will be listed for this entry.
trans-unit.target: If you are configured to use SNI based SSL, or are not configured to use SSL, no address will be listed for this entry.

trans-unit.source: 2. Using the tools provided by your domain name registrar, modify the A record for your custom domain name to point to the IP address from the previous step.
trans-unit.target: 2. Using the tools provided by your domain name registrar, modify the A record for your custom domain name to point to the IP address from the previous step.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you should be able to visit your web app using HTTPS:// instead of HTTP:// to verify that the certificate has been configured correctly.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you should be able to visit your web app using HTTPS:// instead of HTTP:// to verify that the certificate has been configured correctly.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Enforce HTTPS on your web app
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Enforce HTTPS on your web app

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service do not enforce HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service do not enforce HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: Visitors may still access your web app using HTTP, which may compromise your web app's security.
trans-unit.target: Visitors may still access your web app using HTTP, which may compromise your web app's security.

trans-unit.source: If you want to enforce HTTPS for your web app, you can use the URL Rewrite module.
trans-unit.target: If you want to enforce HTTPS for your web app, you can use the URL Rewrite module.

trans-unit.source: The URL Rewrite module is included with Azure App Service, and enables you to define rules that are applied to incoming requests before the requests are handed to your application.
trans-unit.target: The URL Rewrite module is included with Azure App Service, and enables you to define rules that are applied to incoming requests before the requests are handed to your application.

trans-unit.source: It can be used for applications written in any programming language supported by Azure .
trans-unit.target: It can be used for applications written in any programming language supported by Azure .

trans-unit.source: .NET MVC applications should use the <link><linkText>RequireHttps</linkText><title></title></link> filter instead of URL Rewrite.
trans-unit.target: .NET MVC applications should use the <link><linkText>RequireHttps</linkText><title></title></link> filter instead of URL Rewrite.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using RequireHttps, see <link><linkText>Deploy a secure ASP.NET MVC 5 app to a web app</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on using RequireHttps, see <link><linkText>Deploy a secure ASP.NET MVC 5 app to a web app</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For information on programmatic redirection of requests using other programming languages and frameworks, consult the documentation for those technologies.
trans-unit.target: For information on programmatic redirection of requests using other programming languages and frameworks, consult the documentation for those technologies.

trans-unit.source: URL Rewrite rules are defined in a web.config file stored in the root of your application.
trans-unit.target: URL Rewrite rules are defined in a web.config file stored in the root of your application.

trans-unit.source: The following example contains a basic URL Rewrite rule that forces all incoming traffic to use HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: The following example contains a basic URL Rewrite rule that forces all incoming traffic to use HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: URL Rewrite Example Web.Config
trans-unit.target: URL Rewrite Example Web.Config

trans-unit.source: This rule works by returning an HTTP status code of 301 (permanent redirect) when the user requests a page using HTTP.
trans-unit.target: This rule works by returning an HTTP status code of 301 (permanent redirect) when the user requests a page using HTTP.

trans-unit.source: The 301 redirects the request to the same URL as the visitor requested, but replaces the HTTP portion of the request with HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: The 301 redirects the request to the same URL as the visitor requested, but replaces the HTTP portion of the request with HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: For example, HTTP://contoso.com would be redirected to HTTPS://contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: For example, HTTP://contoso.com would be redirected to HTTPS://contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: If your application is written in Node.js, PHP, Python Django, or Java, it probably doesn't include a web.config file.
trans-unit.target: If your application is written in Node.js, PHP, Python Django, or Java, it probably doesn't include a web.config file.

trans-unit.source: However Node.js, Python Django, and Java all actually do use a web.config when hosted on Azure App Service- Azure creates the file automatically during deployment, so you never see it.
trans-unit.target: However Node.js, Python Django, and Java all actually do use a web.config when hosted on Azure App Service- Azure creates the file automatically during deployment, so you never see it.

trans-unit.source: If you include one as part of your application, it will override the one that Azure automatically generates.
trans-unit.target: If you include one as part of your application, it will override the one that Azure automatically generates.

trans-unit.source: .NET
trans-unit.target: .NET

trans-unit.source: For .NET applications, modify the web.config file for your application and add the section from the example to the section.
trans-unit.target: For .NET applications, modify the web.config file for your application and add the section from the example to the section.

trans-unit.source: If your web.config file already includes a section, add the from the example as the first entry in the section.
trans-unit.target: If your web.config file already includes a section, add the from the example as the first entry in the section.

trans-unit.source: PHP
trans-unit.target: PHP

trans-unit.source: For PHP applications, simply save the <link><linkText>example</linkText><title></title></link> as a web.config file in the root of your application, then re-deploy the application to your web app.
trans-unit.target: For PHP applications, simply save the <link><linkText>example</linkText><title></title></link> as a web.config file in the root of your application, then re-deploy the application to your web app.

trans-unit.source: Node.js, Python Django, and Java
trans-unit.target: Node.js, Python Django, and Java

trans-unit.source: A web.config file is automatically created for Node.js, Python Django, and Java apps if they don't already provide one, but it only exists on the server since it is created during deployment.
trans-unit.target: A web.config file is automatically created for Node.js, Python Django, and Java apps if they don't already provide one, but it only exists on the server since it is created during deployment.

trans-unit.source: The automatically generated file contains settings that tell Azure how to host your application.
trans-unit.target: The automatically generated file contains settings that tell Azure how to host your application.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve and modify the auto-generated file from the web app, use the following steps.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve and modify the auto-generated file from the web app, use the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Download the file using FTP (see <link><linkText>Uploading/downloading files over FTP and collecting diagnostics logs</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Download the file using FTP (see <link><linkText>Uploading/downloading files over FTP and collecting diagnostics logs</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Add it to the root of your application.
trans-unit.target: Add it to the root of your application.

trans-unit.source: Add the rewrite rules using the following information.
trans-unit.target: Add the rewrite rules using the following information.

trans-unit.source: Node.js and Python Django
trans-unit.target: Node.js and Python Django

trans-unit.source: The web.config file generated for Node.js and Python Django applications will already have a section, containing entries that are required for the proper functioning of the site.
trans-unit.target: The web.config file generated for Node.js and Python Django applications will already have a section, containing entries that are required for the proper functioning of the site.

trans-unit.source: To force the site to use HTTPS, add the from the example as the first entry in the section.
trans-unit.target: To force the site to use HTTPS, add the from the example as the first entry in the section.

trans-unit.source: This will force HTTPS, while leaving the rest of the rules intact.
trans-unit.target: This will force HTTPS, while leaving the rest of the rules intact.

trans-unit.source: Java
trans-unit.target: Java

trans-unit.source: The web.config file for Java applications using Apache Tomcat do not contain a section, so you must add the section from the example into the section.
trans-unit.target: The web.config file for Java applications using Apache Tomcat do not contain a section, so you must add the section from the example into the section.

trans-unit.source: Redeploy the project (including the updated web.config,) to Azure
trans-unit.target: Redeploy the project (including the updated web.config,) to Azure

trans-unit.source: Once you deploy a web.config with a rewrite rule to force HTTPS, it should take effect immediately and redirect all requests to HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Once you deploy a web.config with a rewrite rule to force HTTPS, it should take effect immediately and redirect all requests to HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the IIS URL Rewrite module, see the <link><linkText>URL Rewrite</linkText><title></title></link> documentation.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the IIS URL Rewrite module, see the <link><linkText>URL Rewrite</linkText><title></title></link> documentation.

trans-unit.source: More Resources
trans-unit.target: More Resources

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: What's changed
trans-unit.target: What's changed

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <link><linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <link><linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title></link>
